title: British Carnatic Choir
text:
The British Carnatic Choir (BCC) is a <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a>-based <a href="Carnatic%20music">Carnatic</a> <a href="choir">choir</a> group, the first of its kind in the country.
It was launched in 2015 by <a href="ShruthiUK">ShruthiUK</a>, a <a href="South%20Asia">South Asia</a>n arts organisation based in <a href="Solihull">Solihull</a> with the aim of creating and exploring <a href="Choir">choral</a> singing in the <a href="Carnatic%20music">South Indian classical music</a> genre. According to its website, the <a href="Musical%20ensemble">ensemble</a> includes children, young adults, music enthusiasts, professionals of both <a href="asian%20people">asian</a> and non-asian origin from across the UK. The British Carnatic Choir organises the annual <a href="World%20Music%20Conference">World Music Conference</a> .
About the Choir.
The choir is the brainchild of <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a>-based Chithra Ramakrishnan, herself a Carnatic vocalist and the artistic director of <a href="ShruthiUK">ShruthiUK</a>, a <a href="Solihull">Solihull</a>-based <a href="Nonprofit%20organization">non-profit</a> South Asian arts and culture organisation. Its website lists notable British names like <a href="Paul%20Sabapathy">Paul Sabapathy</a> (<a href="Royal%20Victorian%20Order">CVO</a> <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">CBE</a>), Carl Rice (<a href="Councillor%23United%20Kingdom">Councillor</a> and <a href="List%20of%20Lord%20Mayors%20of%20Birmingham">ex-Mayor of Birmingham</a>) and Indian ones like <a href="Neyveli%20Santhanagopalan">Neyveli Santhanagopalan</a> and <a href="G.%20J.%20R.%20Krishnan">G. J. R. Krishnan</a> (both <a href="Sangeet%20Natak%20Akademi%20Award">Sangeet Natak Akademi Award</a> winning Carnatic <a href="vocalist">vocalist</a>s), etc. among its patrons.
Performances.
It was officially inaugurated on 12 June 2015 at the Birmingham Chamber of Commerce by <a href="Chitravina%20N.%20Ravikiran">Chitravina N Ravikiran</a>, a composer and scholar in Carnatic music. The choir premiered at the Birmingham Conservatoire in November 2015.
In November 2015 the youth ensemble of this choir performed its inaugural concert with around 120 students from the <a href="Sparkhill">Sparkhill</a>'s Greet Primary School at <a href="South%20and%20City%20College%20Birmingham">South & City College Birmingham</a> auditorium by presenting a series of <a href="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> songs.
World Music Conference.
In November 2017 the group organised the World Music Conference. This is an event aimed at bringing together artistes, academics, music educators spanning diverse cultures from across the world to promote a sense of peace and harmony. The event will be free and conducted annually.
